title: Sloppy baselines and cap heights in ALL Berthold Fonts?
content:
I'm a graphic designer, not a type designer. I just opened up all my Berthold fonts in Type Tool and discovered, much to my dismay, that their fonts seem sloppily drawn: baselines and cap heights consistently don't match one another between letters or even in the same letter. None of my other fonts seem to do this. Is it normal, or are they optical adjustments that I don't understand?

Many thanks for your input!
author: yoshiki

comments.content:
Font names, file dates and formats might help.

Ben Archer mentions the 'special' fonts B hawked in the 80's - [http://typophile.com/node/28845](http://web.archive.org/web/20110314122654/http:/typophile.com/node/28845 "http://typophile.com/node/28845")

Just for example:

UniveBQLig - 5/5/05, T1 Mac  
FuturBQLig - 5/5/05, T1 Mac

But the problem is by no means confined to these...
I would email/write/call the people from whom you licensed the fonts directy and ask them about this, complain really, and see if it wasn't a mistake.

Many foundries used each other's data in the first wave of trying to collect every font in the world (early 90's). So while the outlines of Berthold's Futura might be inconsistent, I'd bet that Berthold's own designs were digitized to an extremely high level of precision. Berthold allowed Adobe to produce and distribute PS versions of their fonts only after Adobe proved that they could match Berthold's data exactly. Check one of the BQ originals like Formata, Comenius or Pontifex.
I think I might switch to Linotype's Univers in that case. What do you think?

Yes. Thanks.

Your screen shots reveal that you are using the raw font files which were produced by the defunct H. Berthold AG prior to its bankruptcy. The entire collection had been hastily scanned and converted to raw fonts in PS font format, but the finishing of the raw fonts was not possible due to the sudden liquidation of the company by the Berlin court.

In my documentation "The mentally deranged graphic designer as font buyer" I proved for another font collection that not all, but most font buyers are mentally deranged graphic designers. For the Berthold "Quality" collection it can be proved too that not all, but most font buyers are mentally deranged graphic designers.

Several years after the liquidation of the H. Berthold AG, an American confidence trickster couple declared themselves to be the legal successors of the defunct H. Berthold AG stock corporation, and after appropriating the raw fonts, they declared themselves to be the copyright owners. For the past 10 years this couple has been selling these raw fonts in order to cheat mentally deranged graphic designers, who have not been mentally able to notice that the "Quality" fonts are the raw, unfinished font files.

During these past 10 years, it seems that Mr. Yoshiki Waterhouse is the first to notice that there is something wrong with the Berthold "Quality" fonts. This proves that not all font buyers are mentally deranged.
